   SpaceX rocket carries the first ever zero-g 3D printer to the Space Station | ExtremeTech
  </title>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190629-spacex-rocket-launches-to-the-space-station-carrying-the-first-ever-zero-g-3d-printer" rel="canonical"/>

  <link href="http://mobile.extremetech.com/latest/222022-spacex-rocket-carries-the-first-ever-zero-g-3d-printer-to-the-space-station" media="only screen and (max-width: 670px)" rel="alternate"/>
  <meta content="SpaceX rocket carries the first ever zero-g 3D printer to the Space Station | ExtremeTech" property="og:title"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" property="og:site_name"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190629-spacex-rocket-launches-to-the-space-station-carrying-the-first-ever-zero-g-3d-printer" property="og:url"/>
  <meta content="Early Sunday morning, SpaceX mission CRS-4 lifted off from Cape Canaveral towards the International Space Station, carrying with it the first 3D printer that will operate in zero gravity. When the astronauts aboard the ISS use the 3D printer, they will become the first humans to ever manufacture goods away from planet Earth. It's not quite the Moon- or Mars-based factory that we've always dreamed of, but it's a very important first step towards manufacturing goods outside of Earth's gravity, and thus the eventual colonization and industrialization of the Solar System." property="og:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3DP_Hardware-short.jpg" property="og:image"/>
  <meta content="summary_large_image" name="twitter:card"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" name="twitter:site"/>
  <meta content="@ExtremeTech" name="twitter:creator"/>
  <meta content="extremetech.com" name="twitter:domain"/>
  <meta content="SpaceX rocket carries the first ever zero-g 3D printer to the Space Station | ExtremeTech" name="twitter:title"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190629-spacex-rocket-launches-to-the-space-station-carrying-the-first-ever-zero-g-3d-printer" name="twitter:url"/>
  <meta content="Early Sunday morning, SpaceX mission CRS-4 lifted off from Cape Canaveral towards the International Space Station, carrying with it the first 3D printer that will operate in zero gravity. When the astronauts aboard the ISS use the 3D printer, they will become the first humans to ever manufacture goods away from planet Earth. It's not quite the Moon- or Mars-based factory that we've always dreamed of, but it's a very important first step towards manufacturing goods outside of Earth's gravity, and thus the eventual colonization and industrialization of the Solar System." name="twitter:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3DP_Hardware-short.jpg" name="twitter:image:src"/>

	           var q = {};
	           if (!url) {
	                 return {};
	           }
	            url.replace(/([^?=&amp;]+)(=([^&amp;]*))?/g, function ($0, $1, $2, $3) { q[$1] = $3; });
	            return q;
	  };

          #stickybanner,

           <a href="http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/jump?iu=/4585/zd.extech/electronicssection_ATF&amp;t=zdid%3D190629%26cmn%3Dzd&amp;sz=970x250|728x90&amp;template=article_sticky&amp;c=7909896&amp;tile=1">

      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">

         SpaceX rocket carries the first ever zero-g 3D printer to the Space Station
        </li>
       </ul>

      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           SpaceX rocket carries the first ever zero-g 3D printer to the Space Station
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/santhony" rel="author" title="Posts by Sebastian Anthony">
              Sebastian Anthony
             </a>
             on September 22, 2014 at 9:58 am
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="190629 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=190629" href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190629-spacex-rocket-launches-to-the-space-station-carrying-the-first-ever-zero-g-3d-printer#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="Made In Space 3D printer, for the International Space Station" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="339" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3DP_Hardware-short-640x339.jpg" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            Early Sunday morning, SpaceX mission CRS-4 lifted off from Cape Canaveral towards the International Space Station, carrying with it the first 3D printer that will operate in zero gravity. When the astronauts aboard the ISS use the 3D printer, they will become the first humans to carry out
            <em>
             off-world
            </em>
            manufacturing.Its not quite the Moon- or Mars-based factory that weve always dreamed of, but its a very important first step towards manufacturing goods outside of Earths gravity, and thus the eventual colonization and industrialization of the Solar System.
           </p>
           <p>
            The Dragon capsule, which launched aboard a Falcon 9 v1.1 rocket, is the fourth of SpaceXs minimum of 12 resupply missions to the ISS. It was carrying 4,885 pounds(2,215 kg) of cargo, including: the RapidScat instrument, which bounces microwaves off the ocean to measure wind speeds; the Kinetic Launcher for Orbital Payload Systems, for shooting mini satellites out into space; the Bone Densitometer (a reduction in bone density is one of the bigger risks of being an astronaut); and the first zero-gravity 3D printer.
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_190633" style="width: 649px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3d-printer-made-in-space-portrait.jpg">
             <img alt="Made In Space's 3D printer" class="size-full wp-image-190633" height="960" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3d-printer-made-in-space-portrait.jpg" width="639"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             Made In Spaces 3D printer. (
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3DP_Hardware-short.jpg">
              View a larger version of the top image
             </a>
             .)
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            <strong>
             Read:
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/115503-what-is-3d-printing">
              What is 3D printing?
             </a>
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            The 3D printer, which is part of the
            <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/experiments/1115.html">
             3D Printing in Zero-G Experiment
            </a>
            , was created by Californian company
            <a href="http://www.madeinspace.us/">
             Made In Space
            </a>
            . I hadntheard of Made In Space before, but it seems like its a small startup that was created for the sole purpose of sending 3D printers into space. It sounds like the zero-gravity 3D printer is much the same as your usual on-Earth 3D printer  though it has been ruggedized to survive launch pressures, and it went through rigorous safety checks to ensure it cant harm the astronauts aboard the ISS. In a conventional 3D printer, gravity is typically used to hold layers in place as theyre deposited  but obviously the Made In Space 3D printer cant do that. (Sadly, the website doesnt say how its done.)
           </p>
           <p>
            <iframe allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" frameborder="0" height="360" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/8ex481nHY7k" width="640">
            </iframe>
           </p>
           <p>
            The first Made In Space 3D printer will use ABS thermoplastic to perform additive manufacturing using standard fused deposition modelling (FDM)  i.e. building objects up layer by layer with molten plastic. The second 3D printer, which is due to go up to the ISS sometime in 2015, will be capable of higher temperature, stronger plastics  and perhaps most interestingly, this second printer willbe an open platform that other companies and institutions can use, to carry out their own tests of 3D printing in spaaaaace.
           </p>
           <p>
            The eventual plan is to install a 3D printer on the International Space Station that can manufacture new and replacement components on an as-needed basis. Additive manufacturing, as long as it actually works in zero-gravity, is perfect for such applications; its faster, more efficient, and simply much easier to make the parts that you need on the ISS (or Mars), rather than repeatedly defeating Earths gravity by burning millions of dollars of rocket fuel.
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_190635" style="width: 650px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3DPrinting2.jpg">
             <img alt="Made In Space, testing their 3D printer during a low-gravity test flight" class="size-large wp-image-190635" height="425" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3DPrinting2-640x425.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             Made In Space, testing their 3D printer during a low-gravity test flight
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            <strong>
             Read:
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190282-nasa-awards-6-8-billion-to-boeing-and-spacex-bringing-spaceflight-back-to-the-usa">
              NASA picks Boeing and SpaceX to bring manned space travel back to the US
             </a>
            </strong>
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignright" id="attachment_140530" style="width: 310px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/slm-nasa-cusing-rocket-part.jpg">
             <img alt="NASA J2-x rocket part, made with an SLM cusing 3D printer" class="size-medium wp-image-140530" height="165" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/slm-nasa-cusing-rocket-part-300x165.jpg" width="300"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             A 3D-printed metal J2-x rocket part, made by NASAs SLM cusing 3D printer.
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            3D printing with plastic is one thing, but the ultimate goal is to perform additive manufacturing with a whole range of materials  most notably, aluminium, and other key metals used in aerospace applications. NASA has spent a lot of time over the last few years working on its additive manufacturing skills  in 2012, it
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/140084-nasa-3d-prints-rocket-parts-with-steel-not-plastic">
             successfully 3D printed a metal rocket engine part
            </a>
            . Im not sure if such 3D-printing-with-metal techniques, such as selective laser melting (SLM), could be carried out on the ISS due to safety and power requirements  but I suspect theyre looking into it.
           </p>
           <p>
            Ultimately, as NASA and other space agencies move towards sending humans to the Moon, asteroids, and Mars, advanced 3D printers are likely to play a key role in humanitys colonization of the Solar System. Weve known for a long time that
            <em>
             anything
            </em>
            we can manufacture off-world  tools, machined components, rocket fuel, water  is a huge, huge step towards long-term human exploration of the cosmos. Sending large amounts of stuff up into space via rockets just isnt workable  we either have to find another way of getting stuff into space (like the mythical space elevator, or fusion engines), or we have to make the stuff outside of Earths gravity.
           </p>
           <p>
            Well be sure to report back in a few weeks,when thefirst plastic widgets and doodads are manufactured aboard the ISS.
           </p>
           <p>
             or
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/152845-nasa-funded-fusion-rocket-could-shoot-humans-to-mars-in-30-days">
             NASA-funded fusion rocket could shoot humans to Mars in 30 days
            </a>
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-thumbnails',
        placement: 'Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-text-links">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-text-links',
        placement: 'Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">
         <div class="holder">
          <div class="widget column widget_tagswidget" id="tagswidget-2">

           </script>
           <div class="title">
            <span class="count">

             </a>
            </span>
            <h3>
             Post a Comment
            </h3>
           </div>
           <div id="disqus_thread">
            <div id="dsq-content">
             <ul id="dsq-comments">
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332656">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332656">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332656">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332656">
                  dc
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332656">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332656">
                 <p>
                  and two days later they were able to produce the solar systems first spaceman figurine to be made in space.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <a href="http://www.123dapp.com/123C-3D-Model/Astronaut-Puppet/1095010" rel="nofollow">
                   http://www.123dapp.com/123C-3D-Model/Astronaut-Puppet/1095010
                  </a>
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332662">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332662">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332662">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332662">
                  Jaye Mathisen
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332662">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332662">
                 <p>
                  WTH is aluminium?
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Quote:
                  <br/>
                  most notably, aluminium, and other key metals used in aerospace applications. 
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Heck, I didnt even know they made keys out of aluminium.  Or aluminum either for that matter
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332664">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332664">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-332664">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-332664">
                    Zunalter
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332664">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332664">
                   <p>
                    Aluminium is the British spelling of Aluminum.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-332665">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332665">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-332665">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-332665">
                      Jaye Mathisen
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332665">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332665">
                     <p>
                      Hmph.  Learn something new every darn day.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-332772">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332772">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-332772">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-332772">
                      Antoine Talbot
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332772">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332772">
                     <p>
                      Less relevant, but in french its also spelled aluminium.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332780">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332780">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-332780">
                   http://www.mrseb.co.uk/
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-332780">
                    Sebastian Anthony
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332780">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332780">
                   <p>
                    For a long time, most of the world (and the scientific bodies/regulators) called it aluminium, while the US always called it aluminum. -ium is the official prefix for elements, and alumina is the ore that its mined/refined from  so it became aluminium.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I think the ruling has since been changed so that both aluminum and aluminium are acceptable, though.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-332892">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332892">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-332892">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-332892">
                      dubious
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332892">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332892">
                     <p>
                      Not sure aluminum instead of aluminium is ever acceptable outside of the US, but it is understood!
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332674">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332674">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332674">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332674">
                  Bumblebee Hive
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332674">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332674">
                 <p>
                  Breaking : Boeing and ULA just announced they will also fly a 3 D printer next time, not made in Russia.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332709">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332709">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332709">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332709">
                  MisterBlat
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332709">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332709">
                 <p>
                  Im more interested in that RapidScat instrument.  Any time not spent on the privvy is more good time for science.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332816">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332816">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-332816">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-332816">
                    Zunalter
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332816">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332816">
                   <p>
                    Unless you are a German scientist, then I think any time spent on the privvy is more good time for science
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332838">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332838">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-332838">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332838">
                  Steven Peters
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332838">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332838">
                 <p>
                  Having used a number of 3D printers I dont see what all the hype is about any of the ones Ive used so far would have no problem working in zero-g.  They dont rely on gravity but hydraulic pressure to extrude the plastic and they stick to the surface being printed on so whats the hype.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-332842">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-332842">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-332842">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-332842">
                    Nick
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332842">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-332842">
                   <p>
                    The MIS guys did a Reddit AMA that addressed this.
                    <br/>
                    <a href="http://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/2gsc8i/our_3d_printer_is_launching_to_the_iss_in_35/" rel="nofollow">
                     http://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/2gsc8i/our_3d_printer_is_launching_to_the_iss_in_35/
                    </a>
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-333358">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-333358">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-333358">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-333358">
                    Boris
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-333358">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-333358">
                   <p>
                    Zero-g should be *better* for 3d-printing.  On the ground, you have to constantly fight gravity to print things like overhangs or thin, long detail.  Can you 3D-print a wirebrush?  A huge headache here, should be no problem in microgravity.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    But what Im really hoping for, is that the printers overall design will get a good work-over before its fully space-worthy.  The current generation of 3d printers is still not nearly as reliable as, say, a common household dishwasher or a vacuum cleaner.  Perhaps this will change by the time NASA is done with it.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-332888">

                 <span id="dsq-author-user-332888">
                  xx

                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-332888">

                  let us dream of the next step:
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <a href="http://www.google.fr/imgres?imgurl=http%3A%2F%2Fhsstudent.newcastle.k12.ok.us%2Ftkennedy%2Fspace%2FMicro.jpg&amp;imgrefurl=http%3A%2F%2Fhsstudent.newcastle.k12.ok.us%2Ftkennedy%2Fspace%2FDEEP.html&amp;h=331&amp;w=589&amp;tbnid=VWxeWshUsnRwFM%3A&amp;zoom=1&amp;docid=rycHIo0AtISQgM&amp;ei=70AhVImZKcnsOqmsgIAH&amp;tbm=isch&amp;iact=rc&amp;uact=3&amp;dur=8696&amp;page=1&amp;start=0&amp;ndsp=20&amp;ved=0CCIQrQMwAA" rel="nofollow">

           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var disqus_url = 'http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/190629-spacex-rocket-launches-to-the-space-station-carrying-the-first-ever-zero-g-3d-printer';
    var disqus_identifier = '190629 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=190629';
    var disqus_container_id = 'disqus_thread';
    var disqus_domain = 'disqus.com';
    var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
    var disqus_title = "SpaceX rocket carries the first ever zero-g 3D printer to the Space Station";
        var disqus_config = function () {
        var config = this; // Access to the config object
        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=190629';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var DsqLocal = {
        'trackbacks': [
        ],
        'trackback_url': "http:\/\/www.extremetech.com\/extreme\/190629-spacex-rocket-launches-to-the-space-station-carrying-the-first-ever-zero-g-3d-printer\/trackback"    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
(function() {
    var dsq = document.createElement('script'); dsq.type = 'text/javascript';
    dsq.async = true;
    dsq.src = '//' + disqus_shortname + '.' + 'disqus.com' + '/embed.js?pname=wordpress&amp;pver=2.74';
    (document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('body')[0]).appendChild(dsq);
})();
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
          </div>

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Electronics'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='Sebastian Anthony';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
        </script>

         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});

  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
  </script>
